components.name: Napthalenesulfonic Acid
components.notes: Formaldehyde-based, %s are of dispersant formulation and will need to be adjusted; "The naphthalenesulfonate dispersant is present in an amount of about 0.1%-3.0% by weight based on the weight of dry stucco."- USG patent

components.name: Boric Acid
components.notes: Biocide, paper adhesion, prevents wrinkles. Present in base wallboard and in gypsum paper GADSL requires reporting over 0.1%. Also see:  Reg. (EC) No 1907/2006 (REACH Candidate List); [0.16 lbs. from base wallboard and (0.01%) and 0.04 lbs. from gypsum paper]

components.name: Water
components.notes: Moisture content of finished product = 3.3% per Athena 2011.

components.name: Vermiculite
components.notes: Fire resistance (listed as standard ingredient in regular wallboard by Athena2011). "Unexpanded vermiculite particles, well distributed in the core, expand when heat is applied, counter-balancing the shrinkage of the gypsum which occurs as it loses its water." (Gypsum 1982)

components.name: Kaolin
components.notes: Found only in Type X, not regular wallboard. Athena2011 explicitly states there is zero clay content in regular wallboard

components.name: Fiberglass (E-Glass)
components.notes: Type X drywall contains small glass fibers designed to increase the boards ability to withstand high temperatures from fires for a longer period of time and thus, would be used in projects that would require higher heat resistance than regular drywall would provide. (Deconstruction and Materials Reuse, Proceedings of the 11th Rinker International Conference, May 7-10, 2003 (Abdol R. Chini, ed.), CIB, International Council for Research and Innovation in Building Construction). "Glass fibers, well dispersed throughout the core, serve as a reinforcing material holding the board core together." (GA 1982)

components.name: Calcium Sulfate Dihydrate
components.notes: AKA land plaster, which is formed after gypsum rock is pulverized and dried. (In wallboard manufacture, this is then calcinated to remove water to produce stucco, the main component of wallboard) (Certainteed TSD)

components.name: Polymer Latex
components.notes: SBR is a representative material stand in for things described as SBR latex, latex, or acrylic. There is variation of the exact polymer used between manufacturers.

components.name: Gypsum
components.notes: Gypsum may be up to 100% post-industrial flue gas desulphurization waste from coal-fired power plants (see residuals).

impurities.name: Formaldehyde
impurities.function: Napthalenesulfonic acid, Formaldehyde polymer, calcium salt residual

environmental.systemBoundary: The system boundary is defined as cradle-to-gate and ends with the finished product at the factory gate. Inbound transportation of significant upstream materials is included; transportation of some minor materials is not included as it is unknown and falls below the cut-off criteria. Operating materials are likewise excluded as they are unknown and fall below the cut-off criteria.

gabiDatasets.name: US: Calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2, dry, slaked lime)
EU-27: Diesel fuel supplied and combusted in diesel generator
US: Thermal energy from natural gas
US: Gypsum (FGD) from hard coal power plant

environmental.endOfLifeTreatment: 100% landfilled (3.3% paper waste, 96.7% inert material), Distance to landfill: 20 miles

name: Type X Drywall
description: Drywall is ubiquitously used in building construction as interior wall enclosures, ceilings, and partitions in both load-bearing and non-load-bearing cases. There are many strains of Drywall including but not limited to acoustical, fire-resistant, moisture-resistant and mold-resistant varieties. This Common Product profile represents a Type X (fire resistant) Drywall product. Drywall is composed of gypsum plaster pressed between a paper or cardboard lining. The key material is gypsum (calcium sulfate), which is available in different hydration levels, and in anhydrous form. Natural gypsum stone is calcium sulfate-dihydrate (CaSO4*2H2O). The anhydrous calcium sulfate can be found in nature as anhydrite (CaSO4). Gypsum also occurs in large quantities as the industry by-product, otherwise known as flue-gas desulphurized (FGD) gypsum. This common product profile includes a combination of natural mined gypsum, FGD, and post-consumer gypsum. Type X drywall has greater thickness and special core additives (mainly vermiculite, fiberglass, and kaolin clay) which provide additional fire resistance, higher rigidity, and enhanced sound attenuation as compared to regular  gypsum  board. 5/8 (16mm) type X North American gypsum  boards are manufactured to ASTM C1396, Standard Specification for Gypsum Board.
